discussion.title: Five of the best books about grief

comments.body: Thinking, today, of anyone who is missing and grieving for someone - and remembering Lucy F, who died suddenly, aged 26, three years ago today. My love to all who loved her.
Levels of Life by Julian Barnes is profound and moving.

responses.body: Amazing book. Thank you for mentioning it. I hope that the comments thread of this could become a rolling resource. I have a collection of books about grief on instagram (it's called thelibraryofloss) - and Barnes's Levels is the very first book I posted there...

So glad this has been mentioned. It resonated profoundly with me after the sudden death of my husband. Others that greatly helped were "A Grief Observed" by CS Lewis (though I am an aetheist) and "You'll Get Over It - The rage of bereavement" by Virginia Ironside.
I still remember when I first read “The levels of life”. It didn’t ‘helped me’ as nothing could ( and can) but somehow made me realize that it is what it is and there is no way out.
That's what I meant by "helped". Helped to navigate the feeling of utter dislocation into some kind of future, given that there is no alternative (once you have decided against the only other one).

comments.body: Paul Auster provides a very interesting and typically idiosyncratic take on grief in The Book of Illusions as his grieving protagonist falls down a rabbit hole occupied by a silent movie star.
As far as picture books go, I don't think you can beat The Paper Dolls by Julia Donaldson.

responses.body: That one really took me surprise as a parent. Thought I was just reading a bedtime story and ended up sobbing beside my three year old...

comments.body: Every, every time, please look to Mum’s Jumper by Jayde Perkin (Book Island). Children’s bereavement can be coated in euphemisms and homilies, frequently showing animals in human experiences. Jayde Perkins’ own experience is shared with such truth and humanity.

responses.body: Thank you for this recommendation - I didn't know it. I will read it and add it to my instagram resource - thelibraryofloss
For very young children, one of the first picture books on bereavement was “Dear Grandma Bunny”, one of the Miffy books by Dick Bruna.

comments.body: May I suggest Susan Hill's In the Springtime of the Year as a fictionalised treatment, please?

responses.body: Absolutely - a classic!
thank you - I haven't read this !

First published 1974 and my copy in the book case is dated 1981 when it had been reprinted.
Moved two years ago and was obliged to give away most of my books but this was a special "must keep" and "must reread" one ......
Oh you have a treat in store!

comments.body: I read The Goldfinch by Donna Tartt while grieving, and found its descriptions of loss extraordinarily perceptive.

responses.body: Similarly, Warlight by Ondaatje is a book with a protagonist damaged by loss and grief
Yes, Tartt really tapped into a kind of verisimilitude on the subject of grief. When on earth is she going to publish another work?
The gaps between her excellent novels have been 10 years, 10y and 11y... the last was published in 2013, so surely another must be dropping soon? I hope so, anyway.
There's talk of a book with the provisional title Tribulation to be published this year — we'll see!
Let us hope so!

comments.body: Toni Morrison's Beloved. So many levels of grief, and a work of genius.

Two memoirs:

Ann Patchett, Truth & beauty, about the friendship between two writers, Patchett and Lucy Grealy, written after Grealy's death.

H is for Hawk by Helen Macdonald, the account of Macdonald trying to tame Mabel, a goshawk, after the death of her father.

responses.body: Loved H is for Hawk.

H is for Hawk by Helen Macdonald, the account of Macdonald trying to tame Mabel, a goshawk, after the death of her father.

Was scrolling down the comments to check whether somebody had already mentioned it :-)!

comments.body: It may seem odd to recommend a funny book about bereavement but I thought this was extremely perceptive: 'Is there anybody out there?' by Marion Keyes

responses.body: Great choice.
I see it's the fourth book in a series. Do you think it would be fine to read as a standalone novel?
It is fine to read as a standalone novel: I did just that last month. I found it funny and heartbreaking, can definitely recommend it.

comments.body: Oscar Hijuelos--Mr. Ive's Christmas
So refreshing to see a list on grief not overwhelmed by Americana (Didion, Tartt, et al).

responses.body: Thank you. I was really quite worried that there would be an outcry about the omission of Didion - I didn't forget her but in the end the only way to do this was to go for a broad-ish range so as to be helpful, but also for the things that spoke most to me personally

I like your list, and was glad that Didion wasnt on it, that book gets trotted out all the time. I just got really irritated by it. But I adore Grief is the thing with feathers, I wish Crow had come to me.

comments.body: I found Rev Richard Coles' book the Madness of Grief very useful. It was like he had a direct line to my thoughts/suffering and was helpful in making me feel less alone in how I was feeling. The Cariad Lloyd one is also good; thank you for these other suggestions.
I particularly appreciate Derry Rees-Jones' poetry collection Burying the Wren

responses.body: Bloody auto correct: Deryn.

Bloody auto correct: Deryn.

The bloody Welsh and their weird names! (It'd be funnier if Mach was online, but I see scarlet is around, so there.)

comments.body:
Riley writes of being “superficially ‘fine’” but “with an unseen crater blown into my head”.

That is as good a description about the feeling of grief as I have ever read.

Michael Rosen's Sad Book was a help. My daughter died unexpectedly in 2011 during a bone marrow transplant, age 7. Her twin sister, now 21, has autism and learning difficulties, she struggled particularly as her sister was almost like her neurotypical conduit and helped her to cope through the early years of her life when they were both at pre-school and in social situations genrally. She needed to try to make sense of her sister's loss in her own way, Rosen's book helped to do that.

responses.body:
She needed to try to make sense of her sister's loss in her own way, Rosen's book helped to do that.

I am so sorry for your loss. I hope, somehow, that Rosen gets to read your comment; I cannot imagine any more rewarding purpose for his book.

comments.body: Colum McCann, Apeirogon. Two fathers, one Israeli, one Palestinian, working through the loss of their daughters to try to bring about peace. Even more resonance with events of the last few months.

While not exactly about grief the chapter in The World According To Garp which follows the car crash, detailing how those involved are recovering but making no reference to one particular character just seemed to highlight the sense of loss.
Drive Your Plow over the Bones of the Dead - not overtly a book about grief, at first, but it is at the heart of everything. The tragic loss becomes simmering outrage.
CS Lewis - A Grief Observed

responses.body: Better than any of these offerings.

Better than any of these offerings.

You've read all five? That's great, could you please tell us why they pale in comparison with the CS Lewis...?

comments.body: A Single Man - quiet, yet devastating sense of loss and loneliness, made all the worse as it cannot be acknowledged, such was society in the early 60s. The film adaptation is also a wonder.

responses.body: Oh, yes, good call — book and film both.

comments.body: "A Little Book of Grieving" by Felix Hewison-Carter is a beautiful publication from Flatland Press. It captures, so simply, those feelings that are so hard to articulate.

Thank you for including Sad Book by Michael Rosen. I agree it's for all ages and isn't that what death is - the final act that 'finds you'.
It's comforting, if that's the right word, to read Sad Book and acknowledge that being sad is ok - it finds you. And sometimes gives you good memories.

I found myself crying repeatedly during the final episode of the current Netflix adaptation of David Nicholls's ONE DAY as Dexter dealt with his grief. If the ending of the book is half as good as the film then it could be added to this list.

responses.body: Oh, it is, it is.

comments.body:
Grief is very multifarious and complex in it's variety.
Coupled with the resistance to discuss it, i think it's diffuclt to generalise about what, in any given form or mode of grief, one can predict a sense of both need or solace.
I Found Ruby Wax's launch of the GoodGrief Festival - https://www.goodgrieffest.com/ - during the pandemic eye opening in terms of exposing and opening up the diversity of experiences of grief and mourning. I note the author Michael Rosen is afflitiated to the festival.
Jenni Diski's In Gratitude, in which she tacked her diagnosis of terminal cancer with her usual mordant, sarcastic, witty manner.

I would recommend Rob Delaney's A Heart That Works about the life and death of his son Henry.

And the children's book Always and Forever by Deb Gliori and Alan Durant is lovely in a sob-inducing way.
Ghost rider by Neil Peart, a healing motorcycle road odyssey after the loss of his wife and daughter.

You might also find this short work by a woman local to me in Norwich, it is beautifully simple and simply beautiful:
https://www.invisibleworks.co.uk/product/a-little-book-of-grieving/

I'd also give a plug to A Manual for Heartache
by Cathy Rentzenbrink

responses.body: Thank you, I’ll read that. Nothing prepares you for it really.

comments.body: The novella I Called Him Necktie by Milena Michiko Flasar. Poetic and dream-like, the work introduces Taguchi Hiro, who has become hikikomori following on from tragic events in his past. Venturing outside for the first time he encounters Ohara Tetsu, a salaryman who eats his carefully prepared lunch every day at the park. The novella explores the relationship that builds between these two misplaced characters, and the shared sadness that binds them. It's such a beautiful little book - I wish more people knew of it.

While my time as a "young adult" is long over, The Astonishing Color of After, a YA novel by Emily X.R. Pan (2018), which I read a few months ago, still resonates with me. It's a very special take on grief, especially regarding a parent's suicide and how "After" may feel.

Thinking of poetry, Douglas Dunn's collection Elegies came to mind first.

The Kaleidoscope

To climb these stairs again, bearing a tray,
Might be to find you pillowed with your books,
Your inventories listing gowns and frocks
As if preparing for a holiday.
Or, turning from the landing, I might find
My presence watched through your kaleidoscope,
A symmetry of husbands, each redesigned
In lovely forms of foresight, prayer and hope.
I climb these stairs a dozen times a day
And, by the open door, wait, looking in
At where you died. My hands become a tray
Offering me, my flesh, my soul, my skin.
Grief wrongs us so. I stand, and wait, and cry
For the absurd forgiveness, not knowing why.

responses.body:
Jesus H Christ @bl, don't make me cry! That is a beautiful poem.

(Glad you came across that YA book. I don't think you've mentioned it on WWR...)

Yes, it's a beautiful, unforgettable poem.

(Me, too - glad alwynne recommended it. I mentioned on WWR that I had packed it, along with too many other books, on going away for a while, but didn't write a review.)

comments.body: The Year of Magical Thinking and Blue Nights by Joan Didion. Grief and loss in hauntingly sparse prose. Makes you think how much loss can a person endure?
The Archeology of Loss by Sarah Tarlow is a wonderful and truthful exploration of all the many facets of loss and grief
The Year of Magical Thinking by the late, great Joan Didion is a searing memoir written following the sudden death of her husband.
Elisabeth Kubler Ross. ON DEATH AND DYING. Around for 50 years and counting. A must read on the subject of mortality.
Notes on Grief - Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.

A surprising addition to the select group of books on grief might be "From Genocide to Generosity - hatreds heal on Rwanda's Hills". It was the INDIEFAB book of the year on the topic of grief and grieving in 2015. Not all the news that comes from Rwanda is bad.

A Heart that Works by Rob Delaney is one of the best books on grief I've read. He really nails how it feels to be dealing with an impossible and unfair situation... and it's surprisingly funny, given the content (though perhaps not given the author).

Also either (or both) The Year of Magical Thinking and Blue Nights by Joan Didion are both excellent.

For me personally, I usually turn to a familiar favorite. After a particularly difficult trauma in 2012, I re-read Neil Gaiman's The Sandman and, in addition to being swept away by the story, found it to be quite poignant when discussing grief and mourning... albeit indirectly, in a lot of ways.
A Grief Observed. C.S. Lewis.
Something Happened by Joseph Heller.
I read "A Monster calls" by Patrick Ness a few years after my Mother died of cancer. It put in the words the anger and frustration and powerlessness I felt at the time.
I Remember Kim, by Rona Cran - a poetic memoir about surviving the loss of a sister.
A novel that deals with sudden death and the effect of grief: A. S. Byatt’s ‘Still Life’.

responses.body: O boy! The unexpected death in that one knocked me sideways-I burst into tears.

comments.body: The most moving depiction of grief that I've read is Donna Macdonald's "Jack's Story", a mothers account of losing her son through Sudden Infant Death Syndrome
Patrimony by Philip Roth
I'm not a fan of his Narnia books but CS Lewis's A Grief Observed is exceptionally good.

I wanted to add one for children, which I still found useful even though I'm an adult: The Heart and the Bottle, by Oliver Jeffers. I'd also like to endorse the suggestion of Cariad Lloyd's 'You Are Not Alone' - I think I've bought four copies for people now.
A couple of people thought it was a great idea to give me copies of Didion's 'Year of Magical Thinking' in the days immediately after my husband died suddenly of a heart condition, and perhaps unsurprisingly I've still not read it over two years later - maybe I'll give it a try this year. I find that just as grief is so personal, so, too, is finding what resonates for each of us.
